title: Kain panjang

  physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It is set against a dark blue background that is decorated with starburst patterns. The kain panjang features an intricate design of flowering tendrils and cloud formations amongst garuda wings and tail feathers. There is a signature on the bottom-right of the batik kain panjang.

  subject_terms_1: Peranakan cultural diffusion foliage (motif)

  subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Batik

  subject_terms_3: Peranakan costumes Batik

  sgcool_label_text: The entire kain panjang is set against a indigo blue ground decorated with starburst background patterns.  Embellished on the surface of the cloth are flowering tendrils
 cloud formations reminiscient of the ancient Cirebon megamendung motif
 and pairs of garuda wings and tail feathers known as sawat.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987)
 the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures
 she used her husband’s name
 Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards
 she used Jane Hendromartono
 combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name
 Hendromartono with Jane
 as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother
 and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds
 rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe
 America and Japan
 especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan”.

metadata.physical_appearance: This is a batik kain panjang. It is set against a dark blue background that is decorated with starburst patterns. The kain panjang features an intricate design of flowering tendrils and cloud formations amongst garuda wings and tail feathers. There is a signature on the bottom-right of the batik kain panjang.
metadata.subject_terms_2: Motifs Ethnic costume Peranakan (Asian people) Culture diffusion Batik
metadata.sgcool_label_text: The entire kain panjang is set against a indigo blue ground decorated with starburst background patterns.  Embellished on the surface of the cloth are flowering tendrils, cloud formations reminiscient of the ancient Cirebon megamendung motif, and pairs of garuda wings and tail feathers known as sawat.  This batik comes from the family collection of Oey Djien Nio (1929-1987), the last in three generations of documented batik-makers in Pekalongan.  In her earlier signatures, she used her husband’s name, Liem Siok Hien.  But from 1965 onwards, she used Jane Hendromartono, combining her husband’s new Indonesian family name, Hendromartono with Jane, as people addressed her by.  She developed a personal style distinct from her mother and grandmother, and experimented with a wide spectrum of colours and exotic combinations of birds, rock formations and mythical animals.  Jane Hendromartono’s clientele expanded beyond the elite in Indonesia to include Europe, America and Japan, especially in the 1980s.  This piece is signed “Hendromartono’s Batik Art” Unique Pekalongan”.
